title: 2020-05-04 - Android SLocker Variant Uses Coronavirus Scare to Take Android Hostage
plain_text:
# Android SLocker Variant Uses Coronavirus Scare to Take Android Hostage

**[labs.bitdefender.com/2020/05/android-slocker-variant-uses-coronavirus-scare-to-take-android-hostage/](https://labs.bitdefender.com/2020/05/android-slocker-variant-uses-coronavirus-scare-to-take-android-hostage/)**

[Anti-Malware Research](http://10.10.0.46/blog/labs/tag/antimalware-research/)

4 min read

[Silviu STAHIE](http://10.10.0.46/blog/labs/author/sstahie/)
May 04, 2020

One product to protect all your devices, without slowing them down.

[Free 90-day trial](http://10.10.0.46/media/html/consumer/new/get-your-90-day-trial-opt/index.html)


-----

The coronavirus pandemic is an opportunity for criminals who try to take advantage of
people‚Äôs thirst for information. Unfortunately, Android users can fall prey to malware attacks
using the COVID-19 cover, especially if they sideload apps by circumventing the installation
process through the official Play Store.

Users are always facing risks when using technology, especially when it‚Äôs connected to the
Internet. One of the ways to increase your possible exposure to Android malware is to
install apps outside of regular vendor-endorsed channels..

And what better way to get people‚Äôs attention than by using an app that‚Äôs simply called
‚ÄúAbout Koronavirus.‚Äù Users with a voracious appetite consume everything that‚Äôs
coronavirus-related, and in this case, the app would lock the screen of the phone,
prompting people to pay for a code to return the control of their device.

While it‚Äôs not as damaging as ransomware, the average user will have a hard time
distinguishing between threats, as the result is the same, and that‚Äôs getting locked out of
your device.

**Sideloading is dangerous**


-----

People should generally be wary of installing applications from sources outside of official
ecosystems, like the Play Store. It‚Äôs a sure way of compromising a phone, whether it‚Äôs
through malware designed to lock the phone or to steal personal or financial information.

Bitdefender telemetry picked up a malware variation of a SLocker ‚Äì a consecrated piece of
malware that locks the user out. The phone itself and the data are not affected, but the
phone becomes unusable, as the home screen is no longer accessible. It‚Äôs not a terribly
clever piece of software ‚Äì and it could‚Äônt be much more, given how Android is built ‚Äì, and
there are ways to remove it even after it became active.

The app is called ‚ÄúKoronavirus haqida‚Äù, which translates into ‚ÄúAbout Coronavirus.‚Äù The
package name is ‚Äúcom.lololo‚Äù (MD5: 476b68a650223780ec73f804e639b7ce) and after the
user installs the application and runs it, the screen is locked and displays a simple
ransomware message, in the Uzbek language.

To make the threat even more convincing, the attacker says that you can only pay within 20
minutes, after which the phone won‚Äôt be usable. The good news is that the time limit is
false, as there‚Äôs nothing like that implemented in the code. The bad news is that the phone
is genuinely locked, which means that none of the buttons will work, and it survives a
system reboot.

Depending on the Android version, the SLocker will behave differently, depending on the
level of access permitted by the OS. Newer Android versions, from 8.0 and upwards, won‚Äôt
allow the app to lock the buttons, but users still can‚Äôt delete the app normally.


-----

This is the rough translation:
```
Congratulations!
Your phone is blocked! You have 20 minutes to enter the code, otherwise the
phone will not turn on again ‚Ä¶
Don't see this as an arbitrary message, it will be difficult for you üôÅ
Unlock password
Exact time
To unlock the code, call +998 998 910 312 Make 8000 paynet and get the
code. (Don't ask for the code without Paynet, I won't tell you anyway)

```
If the user enters the wrong code, a simple message is displayed: ‚ÄúAvval paynet, keyin kod
üòÖ‚Äú that translates to ‚ÄúFirst paynet then code.‚Äù

And here comes the strange part, as the code expected by the app is actually the phone
number, 998 998 910 312, without the ‚Äú+‚Äù sign. It‚Äôs hardcoded into the app, so it‚Äôs the same
one for anyone foolish enough to install the malware.

Just unlocking the phone by entering the right code doesn‚Äôt remove the application. It will
continue to run in the memory until it‚Äôs removed. If the user kills the app from memory and
reruns it, the phone will be locked once more.


-----

You will also notice a checkbox, with the text Nimaga telefon blocklandi?, translating to
‚ÄúWhy is the phone blocked?‚Äù. When the checkbox is selected, the following message is
shown: ‚ÄúYou have installed something prohibited from the internet on your phone. If you do
not PayNet within the specified time, your phone will not light up again. ‚òé Get the code by
dialing + 998 99 891 03 12 for 8000 PayNet sum! ‚Äú, 0‚Äù.

**Lessons to be learned**

Once the user runs the malware and locks the phone, it can only be removed via the
Android Debug Bridge (adb) or Safe Mode. If the correct code is entered and the screen
unlocked, the app can be removed from the OS as well, through the usual methods.

The malware is not as aggressive as others, but the fact that‚Äôs trying to make use of the
coronavirus scare is likely to help it get more traction.

What‚Äôs equally interesting about this SLocker malware is the fact that it‚Äôs not entirely
original. In fact, it‚Äôs most likely a copy of some older versions; it was just adapted to the
COVID-19 pandemic.

When we look closer at the file structure, we see there‚Äôs an image in ‚Äú\res\drawable\‚Äù
named ‚Äúimage_1.png‚Äù that has a message in Russian, and not in Uzbek. The likely
explanation is that it‚Äôs leftover from the previous versions of the screen locker.


-----

The translation you were blocked for cheating.

In the past few months, the malware was reported in Ukraine, Russia, numerous countries
in Central Asia, including Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan, and parts of India and North
Africa.

Various samples with the same package name (Virus or ELOSTORA VIRUS labels), have
been identified as well. However, they have no relation to the Coronavirus, but appeared
after COVID-19 became a pandemic.

**Indicators of compromise:**

MD5 First seen on

6e3d57271a1c0e8e79c88d15f3897bab Nov 30 2019

698aa564ba543d8b0bb247471554672b Feb 21 2020

1dfc2e6f96727ab1bb37bc5ac303dc62 Mar 09 2020

8fc2e3254eabdfceee843c6bc3367f6c Mar 09 2020

c89cd578e2a647671ce7254d3fab41dc Mar 20 2020
